Award.AwardTitle: Randomness in number theory and automorphic forms
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposal is concerned with randomness in number theory .Randomness appears in many forms when studying diophantine problems and it is sometimes transparent ,with the burden being to establish the expected randomness, while in other cases discovering the randomness is already a major issue . The specific settings in which we seek to continue to investigate this phenomenon include diophantine problems connected with orbits of groups of integral affine morphisms ,the randomness in the such sequences as the Mobius function and especially its connection to low complexity dynamical systems ,the randomness in zeros of families of automorphic L-functions and in the zero sets (nodal lines) of the corresponding automorphic forms. Understanding the randomness issue is at the heart of many applications to number theory and arithmetic quantum chaos .


The interplay between number theory and other areas within mathematics has a long tradition.Many fields within mathematics were developed in part to solve problems concerning whole numbers and prime numbers. Naturally these areas continue to play a central role in the theory of numbers . More recent is the interplay between mathematical physics ,theoretical computer science and information theory .This cross fertilization is at the heart of this proposal .For example the modular surface gives perhaps the unique example of a classically chaotic hamiltonian for which the fine points of its quantization can be studied.Techniques from statistical physics and especially random matrix ensembles model precisely the zeros of families of central objects in number theory called "zeta functions" .Ideas from combinatorics and theoretical computer science ,notably "expander graphs", play a central role in understanding some classical number theoretical problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goals of the grant were to a large extent met. A number of questions remain while other fundamental issues that arose during the investigation were identified and resolved. We review the main achievements.

 
The development of a sieve for the action of an integral linear group (potentially a "thin" one) on integer points was initiated in [1] and resolved in full generality in [2]. A survey of the tools that were developed for this purpose is given in [3]. One of these tools is a spectral gap for associated operators controlling equidistribution. We revisited this problem for certain arithmetic situations in the Letter [4] and paper [5]. In these cases one can establish the density of orbits at the smallest possible scale using the Ramanujan Conjectures in the theory of automorphic forms. This has applications to construction of optimal 1-qubit  Universal Quantum Gates; "Golden Gates" (see [5]). What remains to complete the construction of optimal Universal such gates is to do the same for 2-qubits and we have some good candidates for such Golden Gates. The initial steps in developing a diophantine analysis for nonlinear integral affine actions is taken in [6] in the setting of Markoff surfaces and a local to global Hasse principle is investigated in [7]. This appears to be the first non-homogeneous cubic surfaces for which there is now a theory of integral points. In a different direction concerning automorphic Maass forms, [8] develops various tools (which remain the only ones known) to produce nodal domains in the setting of quantizing a classically chaotic Hamiltonian. This led us to the question of the shape (topology) of the nodal set of a random mono-chromatic wave and of a random real high degree hyper-surface in projective space. This is answered in the papers [9] and [10], though the tantalizing question of there being giant percolating component in dimensions 3 and higher remains unresolved.

[1] (with J. Bourgain and A. Gamburd), "Affine linear sieve, expanders and sum product," Invent. Math., (2010), 179, 559-644.

[2] (with A. Salehi), "The Affine Sieve", JAMS 26 (2013) 1085-1105      

[3]    "Notes on thin matrix groups", in "Thin Groups and Superstrong Approximations" 343-362, MSRI Publications Vol 61 (2014), Editors E. Breuillard and H. Oh.

 [4] Letter to S. Aaronson and A. Pollington, "The Solovay Kitaev theorem and golden gates" (2015) https://publications.ias.edu/sarnak/paper/2637

[5] (with O. Parzanchevski) "Super Golden Gates for PU(2)"
Advances in Mathematics, 327 (2018), 869-901      

[6] (with J. Bourgain and A. Gamburd) "Markoff triples and strong approximation", Compes Rendus Math, 354:2 (2016), 131-135.

[7] (with A. Ghosh)  "Integral points on the Markoff type cubic surfaces", arXiv:1706.06712

[8] (with A. Gosh and A. Reznikov) "Nodal domains for Maass forms I" GAFA 23 (2013) 1515-1568.

[9] (with I. Wigman) "Topologies of nodal sets of random band limited functions", arXiv: 1510.08500, to appear in CPAM

[10] (with Y. Canzani) "Topology and nesting of the zero set components of monochromatic random waves", arXiv: 1701.00034, to appear in CPAM.
